prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Overlap with selection of a transferee district

para.paratext: Many of the factors that bear on selection of a transferee district relate to the selection of a judge. For example, although the opportunity to assign the cases to the district with greatest familiarity with the litigation does not necessarily dictate the result of the assignment question, it is closely related.[1] In some cases, the question of selection of an individual judge may relate to the decision on transfer itself—if a particular judge can accept assignment of the cases, then transfer is more likely to be ordered.[2] In other cases, it is apparent that the Panel is discussing attributes of the transferee district court as a whole, and not the particular judge to whom the docket is transferred.[3]

The decisions of the Panel do not always distinguish between factors affecting its selection of a transferee district and those related to the assignment of the cases to a particular judge. The most important reason for distinguishing between the two decisions made by the Panel is that some arguments are logically related only to one of the factors and should therefore only be pressed on that issue. Similarly, some arguments may be effective at rebutting an opponent's arguments on one of these issues, but of little value on the other.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

The role of judicial experience in the particular litigation as a factor in selecting the transferee court is discussed in § 6:14. Examples of situations where the Panel has assigned cases to other judges within the transferee districts are contained in §§ 6:13 and 6:15.

See, e.g., In re Starmed Health Personnel, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 317 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re General Motors Corp. Piston Slap Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1386 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
